373339: Zhur-Taa Druid.author: Veltus
373339: Zhur-Taa Druid.text_parsed: I have a question regarding Zhur-Taa Druid's ability. His ability gives the player an extra forest mana to his mana pool. Does this mana last forever or until the end of the turn?
373339: Zhur-Taa Druid.text_posted: I have a question regarding Zhur-Taa Druid's ability. His ability gives the player an extra forest mana to his mana pool. Does this mana last forever or until the end of the turn?

373339: Zhur-Taa Druid.author: chainsmoker
373339: Zhur-Taa Druid.text_parsed:
@Veltus - I believe the mana pool is emptied as each phase ends. which means, if you have 1 mana left in your mana pool at the 1st main phase, you have 0 mana in that pool as the combat phase starts.
Before, there was this mana burn which deals 1 damage to you for each unused mana in your mana pool but now mana burn is obsolete.
373339: Zhur-Taa Druid.text_posted:
@Veltus - I believe the mana pool is emptied as each phase ends. which means, if you have 1 mana left in your mana pool at the 1st main phase, you have 0 mana in that pool as the combat phase starts. 
Before, there was this mana burn which deals 1 damage to you for each unused mana in your mana pool but now mana burn is obsolete.

373339: Zhur-Taa Druid.author: jonrds
373339: Zhur-Taa Druid.text_parsed:
@veltus
chainsmoker is right, but I wanted to add something. A forest has the same "tap: add one green mana to your mana pool" ability that this guy has. Go look at the old lands, they all still have the ability written on them. They stopped printing it though, thinking it was so obvious no one needed the reminder.

As to this card, im really surprised people don't seem to like it. It just seems so perfect for its colors. Get the mana to put a big creature out, while at the same time getting your opponent that much closer to lethal range. Its very rare that you see really offensive mana ramp (noble hierarch is the only other one that comes to mind), so I would think people would jump on a card like this.

373348: Prey Upon.author: blurrymadness
373348: Prey Upon.text_parsed:
In most cases I'd prefer pit fight simply because it's quite easy to screw with an opponent's blocking plans; hit a creature in response to removal, or other neat tricks.

I.E. "I doom blade your Primeval Titan"
"In response he fights your *insert 4/4+*"

While that may not be optimal in other colors; this isn't bad at all in green. Be very careful when someone can respond to this with a kill spell; netting them a 2-for-1; same with hitting creatures who aren't smaller than what you're fighting with.

Also remember that damage last through the turn; so don't accidentally use this, attack, and lose your fat to a 2/1.

I LOVE the Theros Color Pie! :D It's not REALLY Planar Chaos at all, but comparing it to the Ravnica Color Pie, it *almost* could be.

Wizards, this is how you need to keep the Colors interesting-- turning them around so we see a different look at the same color, rather than twisting (as PC did) and giving us an actually 'new color'.

it's pretty much almost impossible to describe this in terms of the Color Pie we are familiar with (Core Set). And yet, as much as this seems different, it seems like the same Core Color Identities. o.O It feels like it's defying logic with how much it is different and same at the same time XD

this is CREATIVITY DONE RIGHT. :p

373371: Dawnstrike Paladin.author: Galf506
373371: Dawnstrike Paladin.text_parsed:
I gave this card a 3/5 because it's a very solid and cheap card for starters like me.
I don't want to spend more than a bus ticket on cards, and this little knight here can be a very useful cornerstone for the defense of your deck while playing casually. Plus, the art is badass and the flavor text is nice.
It has enough toughness to survive most burns, and most players will save their removals for something scarier, leaving this little card free to act as a lifestealing brick wall. I'm playing one in my aura deck, along some angels, and it's very nice to have with a Divine Favor or Ethereal armor on it.

Of course, for 5cmc there's a sea of cards that are much better, hell even for 4cmc, but this is a dirt cheap common, it's aimed at beginners, and in that role it does a wonderful work. Vigilance and lifesteal ain't nothing to sneeze at.

373373: Ghor-Clan Savage.author: Mode
373373: Ghor-Clan Savage.text_parsed:
"Compare his rating with the rating for the Guildpact printing." —A3Kitsune

The Guildpact printing is more accurate. This card is bad:

If this works out, it's a 5/6 for .
Not too shabby, but compared to other Bloodthirst creatures, which usually come with a higher power than converted cost or other benefits.

Now consider that this is a fact for a reason — activating bloodshirst istn't that easy, particularly later in the game when your opponent had time to build himself up.

Such a high bloodthirst number might seem deceptively good. But when you realize that you just get something slightly larger than a bear for five mana when you can't hit your opponent, you'll realize this is pretty terrible.

373379: Sun Titan.author: CaptainBlue
373379: Sun Titan.text_parsed:
In the background story of this duel deck, there's supposed to be a battle between humans and monsters over a large bridge which spans a wide chasm. It's the only pass between monster and human territories, and the defending humans are trying to hold the attacking beasts off at this key location. Judging by the art, it looks like the titan is standing in the chasm waiting for the enemies' approach.

This guy's scary. I mean, he's tall enough to look over the ledge. He'll be chopping up and stomping out anything brave/stupid enough to try to climb the wall 'til the sun goes down. And when it does, he's got those glowing eyes for added bowel-voiding effect.

Got to say, that's pretty awesome. I think I'd try my luck with the bridge.

4.5/5

373379: Sun Titan.author: non1337
373379: Sun Titan.text_parsed:
Goes infinite when combo with the otherwise harmless Shade's Form.

Play dread and drop this and Shade's Form to your graveyard cheat this into play with reanimation.
Once you get this enchanted by Shade's Form, it becomes almost invincible provided that you have a way to sacrifice it. (Only abilities that can get rid of this are non-targeted global exile or bounce or graveyard hate, as you can sacrifice this anytime it flickers countering any targeted spells, and destroying it does nothing)

And add your favorite sacrifice outlet.
Altar of Dementia: Whole library to graveyard please.
Viscera Seer: Tutor anything on top of your library anytime you want.
Goblin Bombardment: Kill everything and any number of players.
Blasting Station: Oh we don't even need red to kill everything.
Phyrexian Ghoul: Infinite power and toughness.

And you can add permanents with creature comes into or leave battlefield triggers to get infinite mana, infinite card draw, infinite life etc etc to add insult to injury...

And yeah you can make turn 1 kill based on it:
Swamp, Dark Ritual, Dark Ritual, Buried Alive, Shallow Grave.
So this, Blasting Station and Shade's Form to graveyard, pull with shallow grave, attack to pull blasting station. This combo will kill any number of opponents on turn 1 requiring only 5 cards (or turn 2 kill at 3 cards plus two lands).

I could be reading this wrong, but you choose the value for X when you activate monstrosity, then monstrosity resolves and he becomes monstrous. The ability has resolved, so there is no longer an "X" value. The resolution triggers the second ability, which references a value X, but this X has never been instantiated, and therefore has no value. Am I reading the card wrong, or does this card not make any sense? Obviously I understand what Wizards was trying to have the card do, but I don't think that it actually accomplishes that with it's current wording.

373384: Polukranos, World Eater.author: Toraka
373384: Polukranos, World Eater.text_parsed:
Don't get why people get so upset about the XX. Look at other monstrosity costs. Nessian Asp: 6G, Monstrosity 4. Arbor Colossus, 3GGG, Monstrosity 3. Nemesis of Mortals, 7GG, Monstrosity 5, cost reduced. Polis Crusher, 4RG, Monstrosity 3.

XXG is definitely no more than what you would be paying for other monstrosities, with one or two mana stacked on in exchange for making him as big as you want to. And eating the entire enemy board in the process.

Also, you're playing GREEN. If you lack the mana to murderise the opposition efficiently (and just killing three creatures, especially at instant speed, IS efficient already) you may not be playing your colour right. I stuck him in a deck that focuses on generating absurd amounts of mana (Karametra's Acolyte, to name just the worst) and then... profit. Giving him ten counters isn't rare in that deck, and I already saw 25. Okay, my deck might be a bit extreme, but as mentioned, ten (or eleven, to be exact) mana can already mess stuff up quite handily. Don't blame the cards if you can't raise the mana, change your deck. I've been told that Mythics are supposed to be "Build around me". This one definitely is.
He's a mana dump, not a money dump mythic. Deal with it.

Also, lacking Trample? (And Deathtouch, if you're a horrible person?) We have ways. Many ways.

373391: Stun Sniper.author: Antsache
373391: Stun Sniper.text_parsed: She's in the right colors for battalion, but using her to activate it is about the last thing I think of when I see such a great ability. Realistically, there are going to be very few situations where using her to activate a batallion ability is a preferable play to keeping her untapped and threatening her ping. Keeping her back is very often going to force your opponent to not block for fear of that one additional damage letting one of your creatures trade up. Even better, you can then use her on your opponent's turn to stop their biggest targetable creature from swinging back at you.

373396: Anax and Cymede.author: SiamKor
373396: Anax and Cymede.text_parsed:
This compares quite favourably with fan-favourite Mirri, Cat Warrior.

Mirri is a 2/3 First Striker with Vigilance for .

This is a 3/2 First Striker with Vigilance for .

Both are legendary, the CMC is the same, the combined power / toughness is the same, and the specialized cost requires two coloured mana for both, though Mirri is mono-coloured and naturally easier to cast.

The Power / Toughness swap actually improves the creature for aggro and combat (who needs toughness on a first striking vigilante), though making it slightly easier to kill.

In casual constructed (which is where both these cards find a home) the difference may be Pyroclasm or X-spells. There will be times when it dies and Mirri wouldn't, but there will also be times when it wins you the game and Mirri wouldn't.

This leaves the 3rd ability. Mirri has Forestwalk, which is incredibly useful if you find yourself against ramp or other green builds (in particular if you are carrying Rancors, Bonesplitters and Giant Growths) but useless otherwise.

Anax and Cymede have an Heroic 1/3 Overrun ability when you cast a spell that targets them, which requires a specific build to be useful (pump, auras and aggro), but it's not mandatory to build around it. Like Mirri's Forestwalk, if Anax and Cymede's Heroic sits out of the match entirely, you will still have a 3/2 first striking vigilante for CMC .

That's not bad value at all, especially in multi-player, where defensive abilities are of paramount importance.

373397: Fires of Yavimaya.author: DarthParallax
373397: Fires of Yavimaya.text_parsed:
I've been WAITING for this card to get reprinted for SO long :D

And I believe that Haste-granting should be at approximately this power level.

Fervor is simply too unwieldy to truly be good.

Goblin Chieftain strikes a nice compromise and at least proves that Modern Magic doesn't have to be as bad as Fervor >:(

Is this card too powerful? I don't know. It's certainly powerful. It's such a shame that its Dominaria flavor keeps it from ever being Standard Legal again. :/ Knowing Wizards, the excuse of having to reskin it with a name, art, and flavortext would cause them to also take the opportunity to re-develop it to just be not as good as the original, or else bump it up to Rare :P

This is to Enchantments what Lightning Bolt is to Instants. Yeah, it's GOOD. "But" Good as old 60's Spider-man would have said. :P But I think it's not overpowered.

I think if WoTC were just a little nicer, they'd give it back to us in Standard. Instead we get Xenagos right after Domri Rade, which is maybe a good thing for Gruul, but a bad thing for Gruul's PR. Look at Thragtusk XP

Fires of Yavimaya is relatively unoffensive and I think I wouldn't mind losing to it. :)

373406: Ordeal of Purphoros.author: Araes
373406: Ordeal of Purphoros.text_parsed:
I like this. Getting tons of efficiency for a two turn delay (2 mana for +3 and 3 dmg.). On a first turn drop with a decent ability, or 2 toughness, this can be pretty devastating. Quickly takes you out of the range of efficient removal, and the finisher allows you to remove some pretty big threats or potential blockers on the fourth turn. Admittedly, if you've got Aurelia you've probably already won, but becomes super efficient with anything that gives extra attacks or counters.

Also works nicely with cards that natively give counters for attacking/dealing damage (Stromkirk Noble or Curse of Stalked Prey for example) that can often stall out to a good early blocker.

373408: Regrowth.author: Salient
373408: Regrowth.text_parsed:
Fun bit of trivia: Regrowth has to be restricted in Vintage for the same reason Burning Wish does -- it doesn't break the game all by itself, but it lets you get around the restricted list.

Whether by Dredge or by Oath of Druids or by Gifts Ungiven or whatever, lots and lots of cards end up in the graveyard fairly early in a Vintage match. By turn three or four, having four Regrowth and one Wheel of Fortune (or four Burning Wish and one Wheel of Fortune in the sideboard) is almost the same as having five Wheel of Fortune.

Awesome art on this printing. I want eleventy.

For seven mana, I want Sylvan Primordial or even just a simple Kalonian Behmoth. Even in draft, I want more for 7 mana than a conditional 6/6 with a built in fling.

Non-rare green creature cards in the same set include:
Ghor-Clan Savage
Streetbreaker Wurm

Expand this up to the whole block and we get:
Indrik Stomphowler
Siege Wurm
Bramble Elemental

As a reminder, this is excluding multicolored green cards outside of gruul, AND excluding rares, while still staying in Ravnica block.

There are almost always a better card. If I'm playing this in a draft, I am very very sad with my deck and have very low expectations, though It may be slightly better in sealed. If I'm playing casual, I'm not playing this card. A million cheaper cards that are better and more interesting. I'm also not a fan of the art (the art style is all I really have a problem with). Flavor text seems a step too cheesy, and I like silly flavortexts (My favorite is Spire Barrage).

1/5, only reason it's not a 0.5/5 is that circumstances DO exist where I'd play this.
